title: PTD Today — Media
disclaimer: Informational only — AI-generated summaries; may contain errors. Verify with the original video.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Victor Moreno, Product Manager for Cloud Networking at Google, explains how networking must be AI-aware to support inference workloads by using specialized metrics, inference-specific routing, and service-level extensions. Google Cloud's approach—centered on the GKE Inference Gateway and AI-aware load balancing—aims to improve GPU utilization, reduce latency and cold starts, and insert guardrails and API management into the traffic path.
bullets: Traditional network metrics (e.g., CPU) and round-robin load balancing miss GPU saturation and can send traffic to congested replicas.
GKE Inference Gateway and AI-aware load balancing use inference-specific metrics like KV cache utilization and queue depth to identify least-loaded replicas.
Prefix caching and shadow copies let the gateway reuse prefill computations and route requests to replicas with pre-existing context to reduce GPU work and latency.
Body-based routing and LoRA adapter awareness enable model identification and more precise routing for multi-model deployments.
Service Extensions let API management and AI guardrails run in the network path to sanitize prompts/responses and block invalid requests before they reach GPUs.
takeaways: Monitoring and capacity planning should incorporate inference-specific metrics (KV cache use, queue depth) because CPU metrics can miss GPU saturation.
Network-level routing and prefix caching can reduce cold starts and improve GPU utilization, which affects power draw patterns and TCO for GPU-heavy racks.
Inserting guardrails at the network edge can prevent wasted GPU cycles on policy-violating or malformed requests, lowering compute costs and associated energy use.
Service Extensions and unified API routing can simplify network topologies and governance, reducing operational complexity for data center and cloud network teams.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video highlights the importance of anticipating the remaining life of aging steam turbine rotors and deciding next steps to preserve steam plant reliability. It directs viewers to GE Vernova’s resource for guidance on rotor end-of-life (EOL) planning.
bullets: Aging steam turbine rotors are critical to steam plant reliability.
Anticipating remaining rotor life enables informed next-step decisions (repair, refurbish, replace).
The video points to a GE Vernova resource for more detailed rotor EOL guidance.
Context note: GE Vernova states a broader focus on electrification and decarbonization.
takeaways: Assess rotor EOL proactively to reduce risk of unplanned outages that can impact grid stability and data center uptime.
Incorporate rotor life estimates into maintenance, capital planning, and spare-parts strategies to optimize availability and costs.
For critical loads (e.g., data centers), prioritize timely decisions on rotor repairs or replacements to maintain backup and baseload reliability.
Use vendor resources and documented guidance (such as the linked GE Vernova material) to inform technical and procurement choices.

items.title: How CNA accelerates risk assessment with Google Cloud Consulting

ai.summary: Based on the available description, CNA partnered with Google Cloud Consulting to modernize risk assessment by processing terabytes of data for thousands of locations using BigQuery and geospatial analytics. The consulting team built a ground-up solution in six months to enable faster, data-driven underwriting decisions and time savings for underwriters.
bullets: Challenge: process terabytes of data across thousands of locations for risk assessment.
Tech: BigQuery and geospatial analytics were used to analyze location-level risk.
Delivery: Google Cloud Consulting provided specialized technical expertise to build the solution.
Timeline: solution delivered in six months.
Outcome: underwriters gained faster, more informed decision-making and time savings.
takeaways: Large-scale geospatial analytics can accelerate site-level risk assessments relevant to substations, transmission corridors, and data center locations.
BigQuery is presented as a capable platform for terabyte-scale datasets across thousands of asset locations.
Using an external cloud consulting team can compress implementation timelines when internal cloud expertise is limited (six-month example).
Faster, data-driven risk assessments aid quicker site selection, resilience planning, and operational risk mitigation for critical infrastructure.

items.title: Power Up Your Skills with SCADA Ultimate: Solutions & Training

ai.summary: Based on the available description, GE Vernova’s SCADA Ultimate packages SCADA, Historian, and Analytics into a single integrated offering and promotes new training opportunities. The video frames this bundle as a way for users and clients to advance their digital and analytics journey and to maximize value across the Proficy product portfolio.
bullets: Integrates SCADA, Historian, and Analytics into one offering.
Positioned to help customers advance their digital and analytics journey.
Announces newest training opportunities to maximize product benefits.
Linked to GE Vernova’s Proficy® software family (links provided).
Targeted at users and clients seeking integrated OT/IT analytics solutions.
takeaways: For grid and substation operators, a single SCADA+Historian+Analytics package can simplify integration of operational data for analytics-driven workflows.
Data center and renewables power operators can leverage the integrated stack to centralize historical and real‑time data for analytics use cases.
New training offerings are highlighted—useful for upskilling staff to deploy and get more value from the Proficy portfolio.
Assess compatibility with existing Proficy deployments and plan integration testing before rollout.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this PJM Interconnection video states that reliability has been PJM’s primary mission since 1927. It offers an overview of how PJM works to make sure electricity is available when consumers and businesses need it.
bullets: PJM has prioritized reliability since 1927.
The video explains how PJM works to ensure electricity is there when needed.
Focus is on operational assurance and availability of power.
Intended to inform viewers about PJM’s role in keeping the grid reliable.
takeaways: Treat regional grid-operator priorities (like PJM’s focus on reliability) as a planning input for site selection and operations.
Use PJM materials to understand regional availability expectations when designing backup and resilience for data centers and critical facilities.
Align maintenance and contingency plans with how PJM manages electricity availability to reduce outage risk.
Engage with PJM resources or representatives to clarify operational expectations affecting transmission, substations, and interconnected assets.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video emphasizes that power systems must balance reliability, flexibility, and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. It states Hitachi Energy delivers power grid technologies with digital functionality at the core to improve stability, reduce downtime, and optimize performance across the system.
bullets: Power systems need simultaneous reliability, flexibility, and efficiency as capacity increases for the energy transition.
Digital technologies are positioned as central to grid modernization efforts.
Goals called out: improved stability, reduced downtime, and optimized performance.
Solutions are framed as applying across multiple system levels (end-to-end).
takeaways: Prioritize digital upgrades that target stability and downtime reduction when planning grid or data center power investments.
Plan capacity expansion with a focus on maintaining reliability and operational flexibility for renewables integration.
Evaluate vendor solutions for system‑level performance optimization rather than isolated component upgrades.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video frames resilient industries as reliant on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration. Hitachi Energy highlights working with customers and partners to build smarter systems that boost productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Resilience depends on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration.
Hitachi Energy collaborates with customers and partners to deliver smarter systems.
Goals emphasized: improved productivity, enhanced reliability, and greater sustainability.
Applicability spans industrial operations and related infrastructure.
Calls attention to integrated, system-level solutions rather than single-point fixes.
takeaways: Prioritize energy-efficiency and process-optimization projects to strengthen operational resilience.
Invest in digital integration to improve reliability and productivity across grid and facility assets.
Seek collaborative vendor/partner engagements for system-level deployments rather than isolated upgrades.
Align modernization efforts with sustainability objectives to meet operational and regulatory expectations.

items.title: Air Taxis Are Coming to Dubai

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Joby Aviation will likely begin an air taxi service in Dubai in 2026, offering quick shuttles across the city to bypass traffic. No transcript is available; the posted description frames the service as a near-term travel option and asks whether viewers would ride.
bullets: Joby Aviation likely to start air taxi service in Dubai in 2026.
Service pitched as a fast way to beat Dubai traffic with short city shuttles.
Description contains no transcript; only a brief promotional summary and hashtags.
Tagged topics include eVTOL, air travel, Joby, and urban innovation.
Viewer prompt: “Would you ride an air taxi?”
takeaways: If the service uses eVTOL aircraft (hashtag #evtol), operators and planners should consider potential localized electric charging demand at vertiports and the associated impact on distribution capacity.
Assess need for resilient power at proposed vertiport sites—backup power, redundant feeds, or substation upgrades may be required to support operations and safety systems.

Data and communications requirements for fleet operations and traffic management could increase demand for low-latency connectivity and edge compute near hubs—coordinate with data-center and network teams.

Procurement and infrastructure teams should monitor battery and critical-minerals supply chains if eVTOL electrification is confirmed, as fleet scale-up could influence long-term sourcing and maintenance planning.
